turn.text: Well, first of all, each and every time with his own counsel, Justice Scalia, he was adamant about asserting his innocence.

You have to appreciate that at this point in time, when there's a discussion about, you know, what a prize -- and it is our position that this action ends, if you will, okay, if the Court grants him access to the evidence under 1983.
And as was pointed out earlier during the argument of my adversary, there is a possibility that -- that the testing -- because, look, I wasn't at the -- at the commission of the crime.
I don't have a videotape in my head.
I'm trying to be as honest and forthright with you as I possibly can.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What if there was a videotape?
Is that covered by the constitutional right you are asserting?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: I -- well, you know, given what I now know about--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Or photographs or other evidence that--

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: --I don't think so.
Given what I now know about Photo Shop, I don't have ----
[Laughter]
--I don't necessarily hold out that much reliability for that either, Justice Roberts.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --That's a good point.
What -- how long under the Constitution does the State have to retain this evidence?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: Under the Constitution there is no duty under current law to preserve the evidence.
We--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Would that be a corollary of the constitutional right you are asking for here?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: --I don't believe so.
I -- however, with one caveat.

And the one caveat is it is a different situation if a person like Mr. Osborne or somebody else specifically says, I want to do DNA testing in this case, files whatever appropriate procedure in whatever court to commence that action, and then, and only then, the other side goes out and destroys the res that is the subject of that litigation.
At that point I think that would be in bad faith.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: No.
I agree that would be -- that -- yes.
I am just wondering if there would be any objection to an absolute rule that says what -- after two years, after one year of conviction?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: No -- no objection.

But on a practical level again, what we're seeing is that States all over the country want to preserve this evidence, not just for the wrongful conviction cases but also to enable detectives who are working cold cases to have access to evidence.
And if the evidence isn't there any more, they can't work them.
So we're seeing a movement across the country now to preserve that evidence.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: May I -- may I just ask one point?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I take it he is not now in custody for this offense?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: I believe he is in custody--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Not for this offense?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: --Well, I -- I think what happened is -- and I -- and I -- I can't swear to this -- is -- is he was -- he got a conditional release on the other matter.
And then the conditional release was violated as well.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: He's being held on other charges.

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But he's not now in custody for this offense.

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: He's -- he's not, but I don't think that would make a difference in the outcome.
Certainly, if a person had a death warrant in one State and then they were charged in another State, they would still have a liberty interest in the outcome of that other case.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Was he released on parole with respect to this offense?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: I -- I believe he -- he was released on what's called conditional release.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And was his confession a necessary predicate to that release?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: Well, under Alaska law one of the key requirements to get parole is that you accept responsibility for the crime.
And so without a certain--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So a confession that would be perjurious if he claimed actual innocence now was responsible for his release?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: --I would hope, Mr. Chief Justice, that I would be principled enough that if I was actually innocent and they told me that the only way I could get out was to say I committed a crime, that I might say:
"Forget it. "
"I'll spend the next thirty years in prison. "
But I can certainly understand--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: No, I understand -- I understand that.

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But he's been -- other than other crimes he committed, he's been released on the basis of what you say is an unprincipled confession.
And now he is--

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: I believe he has been -- he's back in, though, I think, because of the conditional release.
It's been violated.
One second.

He had a parole -- I'm -- I'm told that he had a parole revocation hearing on the other case and that he was given six more years to serve on the -- on the underlying case which is the core of this oral argument.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --So his parole was revoked because he committed another offense?

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: That's my understanding.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Okay.
Thank you, counsel.

turn.speaker: peter_neufeld
turn.label: Mr. Peter Neufeld
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Counsel, we'll give you three more minutes.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: Three minutes, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I -- before you start, would you -- I want you to clear up the question that Justice Breyer asked.
Assume that on remand he would now make the declaration under perjury that he's innocent.
I understood you to say that would enable him to get discovery, but not necessarily to say he would get the DNA evidence.
Am I right?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: If he were to file a new application for postconviction relief with an affidavit that the civil rules of discovery would apply, and he, I believe, would be -- be able to obtain the evidence that he seeks.
However--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: How about--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would you resist that request?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Well, there are -- there are possibilities of procedural default.
But -- and that would be for the court--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You cannot confirm that you would acquiesce and recommend that he get the DNA sample under those conditions?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --I -- yes.
I -- I believe I could.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you would still want to leave yourself open to make the objection that he had a chance to get this at trial and -- and -- and decided not to get it.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: As I say--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wouldn't those objections continue to apply?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, it -- it seems to me that -- that all -- all that you have to concede is that there is some means for him to get into court, with those -- those exceptions that other States make; and other States do make an exception for gaming the system.

So, so long as he can get in in habeas corpus it seems to me you can very well leave for later whether you are going to concede that even though -- even though he didn't ask for it at trial, he can get it now.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --That's true, Your Honor.
And -- and that was--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, why give it away?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --any more than you gave away the fact that this is going to is going to prove his innocence--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why don't--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: We would like to know what you do--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why don't we do it -- I'm sorry.
Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Yes.
I just want to be sure.
Your answer, as I understand it, is he can now apply for discovery, but you don't know what will happen then.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Well, before you reach the discovery issues there would be the issues of procedural default.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: Once those were cleared away then he would be able to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the net result is that it is perfectly clear to me from the argument that you have not conceded that if he now files the paper, he will definitely get the DNA.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Not that he would -- that's correct.
Not that he will definitely get that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: I want to clear up--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But you -- you referred to the civil rules, and in discovery, in criminal cases as in civil cases, it -- ordinarily you have to prove that you have a basis for a claim.
Like you don't get on the civil side discovery before you can pass the 12(b)(6) threshold that you have stated a claim.
Are you giving that up here?
Because he's seeking the discovery but he hasn't established that he has a tenable claim.

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Justice Ginsburg, Mr. Osborne, by filing an affidavit that would accompany his application, that would -- I think that would operate to state a claim.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would there be instances when you, as the Attorney General of Alaska, would waive procedural defaults, in order to determine if there was guilt or innocence in a case where DNA conclusively proved it, simply because of your interest in not confining innocent people?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: That -- that's conceivable, Your Honor; but in -- in Mr. Osborne's case, he's had 14 years to step forward and declare his innocence, as any truly innocent--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All you can say in answer to my question, as to your particular approach to your duties here, is that that's conceivable?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
It -- it is.
Because I don't think that the mere existence of the possibility that DNA could exonerate is necessarily sufficient -- a sufficient basis to then do the testing.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Okay.
This is where I -- look.
He files a new piece of paper.

Now, if you're going to oppose that, on the ground that it wasn't procedurally correct, one; on the ground, two, he didn't ask for this DNA at trial, though he might have; met with the charge, what was at issue at trial is something very different; three, that he wasn't guilty -- you know, too much evidence against him, met with the claim, there wasn't much evidence against him -- okay, we have the case in front of us; we'll decide it.
But if you're prepared to concede,
"I'm not going to raise those things. "
then their client has what he wants -- the DNA.
So which is it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: I -- I'm not sure I understand your -- your question, Your Honor.
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I want to just repeat it.
I -- he -- his client follows your procedure: DNA> ["].
Now will you give it to him?
Or are you going to meet him with the same defenses that you raise here?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Wrong procedure.
You ask -- you could have gotten it at trial, which he says isn't true -- and there was too much evidence, which he says isn't true.
Okay?
So what are we going to have, Mr. Rosenstein?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --If he -- if he were to do as you say, then with respect to a -- the request for discovery, I believe that our only defense would be the procedural defense of -- you know -- lack of due diligence or -- or something along -- or untimely--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If the only defense is procedure--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --that defense--

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --If he walks into court and swears,
"I am innocent, subject to penalties of perjury. "
"Please let me look at the DNA. "
as I understand your answer, your answer will be,
"we will then raise issues of procedural default, waiver. "
et cetera.
You will not say, on the contrary:
"Let him look at the DNA. "
Is that -- is my understanding correct?

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: I -- I can't say that we would actually do that, but we certainly have the -- the right to do that.
And there's nothing wrong with proceeding--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In any--

turn.speaker: kenneth_m_rosenstein
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth M. Rosenstein
turn.text: --Thank you.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.
